<a href="https://simplisafe.com/save?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=20210705&utm_content=link1" style="border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank" class=""><img alt="SimpliSafe" style="width:100%;max-width: 150px; display: inline; vertical-align: middle;" width="150" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL2NvbXBhbnkvbG9nby8xNy8xNTc2MDc3MTcyLWxvZ29fbm9sb2NrLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6ImNvbWV0LW1vcm5pbmdicmV3IiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0="></a>
</th>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>So it’s technically July 5th but it’s <em>also</em> technically July 4th, in the sense that the markets are closed for the federal holiday and many of you are enjoying the third day of what we hope has been an epic weekend so far. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Instead of a standard Brew newsletter, we’ve decided to dedicate this issue to one particular topic that is probably on your minds: jobs. Read on for info on the "Great Resignation," youth employment prospects, and the surge in hiring bonuses.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">See you tomorrow morning with regularly scheduled programming.</p>
</td>
</tr>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
JOBS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/02/diving-great-resignation-means-american-workers?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
"I Quit"—Basically Everybody
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/02/diving-great-resignation-means-american-workers?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Peggy quitting her job on Mad Men" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NjQ4L3BlZ2d5X3F1aXR0aW5nX29uX21hZF9tZW4ucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Mad Men</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Prepare your liver for a marathon of farewell happy hours. A bunch of your coworkers are going to quit their jobs over the next few months—if you don’t leave before then. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In what’s been dubbed the “Great Resignation,” 4 million people, or 2.7% of US workers, quit their jobs in April. That’s a record going back to 2000. In all, <a href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/worklab/work-trend-index/hybrid-work?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">41% of workers globally</a> are considering leaving their current employer this year, according to a survey from Microsoft.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why? </strong>Experts have floated <a href="https://www.npr.org/2021/06/24/1007914455/as-the-pandemic-recedes-millions-of-workers-are-saying-i-quit?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">several explanations</a> to interpret all the quitting:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Workers who didn't like their jobs but stuck with it during the pandemic are...not sticking with it anymore. </span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Many are </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-30/more-americans-are-considering-retirement-because-of-covid?sref=KkPzpZvz" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">retiring early</a></span><span> after cashing in on a booming stock market and rising home values.</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>People have reevaluated their career paths after an "unprecedented" year which allowed for more reflection.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In that same vein, people might be looking for a job that allows for better work-life balance.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">However, the main reason employees are quitting their jobs en masse, Harvard economics professor Jason Furman <a href="https://www.piie.com/blogs/realtime-economic-issues-watch/us-workers-are-quitting-jobs-historic-rates-and-many-unemployed?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">argues</a>, is simpler: There are a record number of job openings in the US right now (9.3 million), and in any economy where lots of jobs are available, people leave their existing roles for greener pastures.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> Has the Great Resignation given workers the upper hand in power struggles with their bosses? Some say <a href="https://www.axios.com/workers-employers-power-unions-wages-pandemic-2d375522-8643-4eae-a88e-d5ecdd055525.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">absolutely</a>. There’s one story of a woman in Georgia who <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-01/return-to-office-employees-are-quitting-instead-of-giving-up-work-from-home?sref=KkPzpZvz" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">quit her job</a> after being asked to go into the office for a six-minute meeting. Wages are rising quickly and companies are offering tremendous perks in their desperation to land employees. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Others argue that when this all shakes out—when extra unemployment benefits end in September and the “reopening” reverts to simply “open”—the mad scramble to find employees will fade as workers settle into their new positions. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For now, at least, all the leverage is with the employee. If they’re not pampered, they’re skedaddling. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ Optional homework: </strong>Here’s a <a href="https://flipboard.com/@feedthemalik/labor-shortage-great-realignment-jcadkvmaakls4d6a?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">collection of articles</a> that discuss the Great Resignation from a variety of perspectives and a <a href="https://vm.tiktok.com/ZMd9CeMuH/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">fun, related video</a> from the Morning Brew TikTokers.</p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/02/postings-hr-roles-jump-53-prepandemic-levels?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Hiring Inception
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/02/postings-hr-roles-jump-53-prepandemic-levels?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="HR Job Posting chart" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NjQ5L2hyX2pvYl9wb3N0aW5nX2NoYXJ0LnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Indeed</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Companies need to hire, but to do that they first need to hire the people who do the hiring.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Postings for human resources jobs have jumped to <a href="https://www.hiringlab.org/2021/06/22/job-postings-through-june-18-2021/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">52.5% above</a> the pre-pandemic baseline, according to research from Indeed. It’s a stunning comeback for HR departments, where postings plunged to 56% below pre-pandemic levels in May 2020. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
YOUTH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/02/exclusive-whats-job-market-college-students-like-summer?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Not Another Hot Take on Working Young People
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/02/exclusive-whats-job-market-college-students-like-summer?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="College campus" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC85NzkvY29sbGVnZV9jYW1wdXMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Pixabay</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The kids are definitely alright. After the unemployment rate for younger workers shot up to 32% last summer, the jobless rate for teens dropped to 9.6% this May, the lowest it's been since 1953, and stayed pretty steady in June at 9.9%. Employment among America’s youth is recovering at a much quicker rate than for any other demographic. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a Morning Brew + Generation Lab <a href="https://www.generationlab.org/post/the-student-job-comeback?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">poll</a>, we asked 500 college students about their work plans for this summer and how they're feeling about it. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">About 72% of our new best friends had some kind of employment lined up for this summer, ranging from a part-time internship to a full-time job. Yet racial disparities persist: 81% of white students had jobs compared to 66% of Asian, 63% of Hispanic, and 51% of Black students.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What else we learned</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">1. That’s a big paycheck you got there. </strong>43% of respondents said they're getting paid more than they were last summer, reflecting rising wages across the labor market. Healthcare (20%) is the most popular field for college student employment this summer, followed by food service (12%).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">2. Think twice before signing up for LinkedIn Premium.</strong> 38% of students found work through family or friends, compared to 18% through job boards. 46% cited college and personal expenses as their main reason for working this summer, while gaining experience was most important to 28% of respondents.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">3. Small staff, open schedule, might lose. </strong>Sign of the times: 31% of students said their biggest concern when going to work this summer was understaffing at their employers, beating out worries over health and safety and working remotely. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">
<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F02%2Fexclusive-whats-job-market-college-students-like-summer" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e865734bf6f7.jpg">
</a><span>  </span>
<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=In+a+Morning+Brew+%2B+Generation+Lab+poll%2C+we+asked+500+students+what+they%E2%80%99re+doing+and+how+they+feel+about+it&url=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/02/exclusive-whats-job-market-college-students-like-summer&via=MorningBrew" target="_blank" rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none;" class="">
<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e86574d1eb82.jpg">

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/03/help-definitely-wanted-restaurant-industry-faces-labor-crunch?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Low Appetite for Restaurant Work
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="McDonald's sign advertising job openings" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NjYyL21jZG9uYWxkX3Nfc2lnbl9hZHZlcnRpc2luZ19qb2Jfb3BlbmluZ3MuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you’re searching for the epicenter of the labor crunch in the US, look no further than the restaurant industry. Restaurants are producing more “We’re Hiring” signs than burgers—but hosts, line cooks, and waiters aren't rushing back to the kitchen. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Surveying the damage: </strong>Around <a href="https://www.marketwatch.com/story/this-industry-saw-a-116-rise-in-job-openings-since-the-pandemic-and-its-not-leisure-and-hospitality-11623242917?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">8.2 million</a> people who worked in the leisure and hospitality industries were laid off between February and April last year when the pandemic first hit. Now, business owners are desperate to fill 1.6 million job openings. One out of every 10 jobs in the sector was unfilled in the spring. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Where did they go? </strong>Many owners say extra unemployment benefits have dissuaded employees from returning. But many former restaurant workers also found more stable jobs in other industries and didn’t look back. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>After surveying over 2,800 food service workers, UC Berkeley Food Labor Research Center said the top three reasons that they’d leave their jobs are low wages and tips, lingering Covid-19 fears, and concerns of hostility from customers.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>The biggest problem facing the restaurant sector predates the pandemic—for many employees it simply wasn’t a fulfilling, safe, or lucrative place to work. "The restaurant business, inherently and pre-Covid, was a toxic workplace," North Carolina restaurant owner Patrick Whalen <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/05/10/economy/labor-shortages-pay-gaps/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told CNN</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>as they compete with one another for workers, restaurants must address those larger issues (higher pay, more welcoming culture) to enjoy a full recovery from the pandemic. It looks like it's beginning to work: Bars and restaurants accounted for nearly 190,000 out of the 850,000 total job gains in June.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
WORK
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/03/companies-offer-lucrative-incentives-lure-workers?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
You’re Hired! Here’s a Tesla.
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Okay, maybe hiring managers aren’t going <em>quite</em> that ham, but to hire the best talent from the US’ limited labor pool companies are getting sample-sale-level competitive. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Postings featuring hiring incentives have <a href="https://www.hiringlab.org/2021/06/24/employer-use-of-hiring-incentives-grows/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more than doubled</a> on the job search platform Indeed compared to last year. And workers have caught on: Searches for jobs that advertise bonuses have jumped 134% since January.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A few examples: </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Nine months after laying off ~32,000 employees, Disney is offering $1,000 bonuses to recruit some workers for its Florida theme parks.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Meat processor JBS will pay for a </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/08/business/economy/jobs-hiring-incentives.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">college degree</a></span><span> for its workers and one of their children.</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>One Jersey Mike’s Subs in Santa Cruz, CA, </span><span><a href="https://www.ksbw.com/article/facing-slow-hiring-santa-cruz-sandwich-shop-offers-dollar10000-incentive/36624680?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">is offering</a></span><span> a $10,000 incentive for an assistant manager and $5,000 for a shift leader.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Employers prefer using cash incentives because they’re effective at catching job seekers’ attention as they scroll through listings, according to Indeed. Plus, a bonus is a one-time commitment rather than an ongoing cost—such as a salary bump or additional PTO.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still, while incentives have become more popular they're only advertised in 4.2% of total job postings on Indeed.</p>

That’s a record going back to 2000. In all, \u003ca href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/worklab/work-trend-index/hybrid-work?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e41% of workers globally\u003c/a\u003e are considering leaving their current employer this year, according to a survey from Microsoft.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy? \u003c/strong\u003eExperts have floated \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2021/06/24/1007914455/as-the-pandemic-recedes-millions-of-workers-are-saying-i-quit?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eseveral explanations\u003c/a\u003e to interpret all the quitting:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWorkers who didn't like their jobs but stuck with it during the pandemic are...not sticking with it anymore. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eMany are \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-30/more-americans-are-considering-retirement-because-of-covid?sref=KkPzpZvz\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eretiring early\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e after cashing in on a booming stock market and rising home values.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePeople have reevaluated their career paths after an \"unprecedented\" year which allowed for more reflection.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn that same vein, people might be looking for a job that allows for better work-life balance.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHowever, the main reason employees are quitting their jobs en masse, Harvard economics professor Jason Furman \u003ca href=\"https://www.piie.com/blogs/realtime-economic-issues-watch/us-workers-are-quitting-jobs-historic-rates-and-many-unemployed?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eargues\u003c/a\u003e, is simpler: There are a record number of job openings in the US right now (9.3 million), and in any economy where lots of jobs are available, people leave their existing roles for greener pastures.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e Has the Great Resignation given workers the upper hand in power struggles with their bosses? Some say \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/workers-employers-power-unions-wages-pandemic-2d375522-8643-4eae-a88e-d5ecdd055525.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eabsolutely\u003c/a\u003e. There’s one story of a woman in Georgia who \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-01/return-to-office-employees-are-quitting-instead-of-giving-up-work-from-home?sref=KkPzpZvz\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003equit her job\u003c/a\u003e after being asked to go into the office for a six-minute meeting. Wages are rising quickly and companies are offering tremendous perks in their desperation to land employees. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOthers argue that when this all shakes out—when extra unemployment benefits end in September and the “reopening” reverts to simply “open”—the mad scramble to find employees will fade as workers settle into their new positions. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor now, at least, all the leverage is with the employee. If they’re not pampered, they’re skedaddling. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ Optional homework: rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecollection of articles\u003c/a\u003e that discuss the Great Resignation from a variety of perspectives width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe kids are definitely alright. After the unemployment rate for younger workers shot up to 32% last summer, the jobless rate for teens dropped to 9.6% this May, the lowest it's been since 1953, and stayed pretty steady in June at 9.9%. Employment among America’s youth is recovering at a much quicker rate than for any other demographic. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn a Morning Brew + Generation Lab \u003ca href=\"https://www.generationlab.org/post/the-student-job-comeback?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epoll\u003c/a\u003e, we asked 500 college students about their work plans for this summer and how they're feeling about it. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAbout 72% of our new best friends had some kind of employment lined up for this summer, ranging from a part-time internship to a full-time job. Yet racial disparities persist: 81% of white students had jobs compared to 66% of Asian, 63% of Hispanic, and 51% of Black students.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat else we learned\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e1. That’s a big paycheck you got there. \u003c/strong\u003e43% of respondents said they're getting paid more than they were last summer, reflecting rising wages across the labor market. Healthcare (20%) is the most popular field for college student employment this summer, followed by food service (12%).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e2. Think twice before signing up for LinkedIn Premium.\u003c/strong\u003e 38% of students found work through family or friends, compared to 18% through job boards. 46% cited college and personal expenses as their main reason for working this summer, while gaining experience was most important to 28% of respondents.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e3. Small staff, open schedule, might lose. \u003c/strong\u003eSign of the times: 31% of students said their biggest concern when going to work this summer was understaffing at their employers, beating out worries over health and safety and working remotely. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you’re searching for the epicenter of the labor crunch in the US, look no further than the restaurant industry. Restaurants are producing more “We’re Hiring” signs than burgers—but hosts, line cooks, and waiters aren't rushing back to the kitchen. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSurveying the damage: \u003c/strong\u003eAround \u003ca href=\"https://www.marketwatch.com/story/this-industry-saw-a-116-rise-in-job-openings-since-the-pandemic-and-its-not-leisure-and-hospitality-11623242917?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e8.2 million\u003c/a\u003e people who worked in the leisure and hospitality industries were laid off between February and April last year when the pandemic first hit. Now, business owners are desperate to fill 1.6 million job openings. One out of every 10 jobs in the sector was unfilled in the spring. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhere did they go? \u003c/strong\u003eMany owners say extra unemployment benefits have dissuaded employees from returning. But many former restaurant workers also found more stable jobs in other industries and didn’t look back. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAfter surveying over 2,800 food service workers, UC Berkeley Food Labor Research Center said the top three reasons that they’d leave their jobs are low wages and tips, lingering Covid-19 fears, and concerns of hostility from customers.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThe biggest problem facing the restaurant sector predates the pandemic—for many employees it simply wasn’t a fulfilling, safe, or lucrative place to work. \"The restaurant business, inherently and pre-Covid, was a toxic workplace,\" North Carolina restaurant owner Patrick Whalen \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/05/10/economy/labor-shortages-pay-gaps/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold CNN\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003eas they compete with one another for workers, restaurants must address those larger issues (higher pay, more welcoming culture) to enjoy a full recovery from the pandemic. It looks like it's beginning to work: Bars and restaurants accounted for nearly 190,000 out of the 850,000 total job gains in June.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F03%2Fhelp-definitely-wanted-restaurant-industry-faces-labor-crunch\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block; Here’s a Tesla.\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOkay, maybe hiring managers aren’t going \u003cem\u003equite\u003c/em\u003e that ham, but to hire the best talent from the US’ limited labor pool companies are getting sample-sale-level competitive. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePostings featuring hiring incentives have \u003ca href=\"https://www.hiringlab.org/2021/06/24/employer-use-of-hiring-incentives-grows/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emore than doubled\u003c/a\u003e on the job search platform Indeed compared to last year. And workers have caught on: Searches for jobs that advertise bonuses have jumped 134% since January.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA few examples: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNine months after laying off ~32,000 employees, Disney is offering $1,000 bonuses to recruit some workers for its Florida theme parks.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eMeat processor JBS will pay for a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/08/business/economy/jobs-hiring-incentives.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecollege degree\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e for its workers and one of their children.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eOne Jersey Mike’s Subs in Santa Cruz, CA, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.ksbw.com/article/facing-slow-hiring-santa-cruz-sandwich-shop-offers-dollar10000-incentive/36624680?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eis offering\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e a $10,000 incentive for an assistant manager and $5,000 for a shift leader.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eEmployers prefer using cash incentives because they’re effective at catching job seekers’ attention as they scroll through listings, according to Indeed. Plus, a bonus is a one-time commitment rather than an ongoing cost—such as a salary bump or additional PTO.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStill, while incentives have become more popular they're only advertised in 4.2% of total job postings on
